sourceMeaningMnemonic: Your <radical>clan</radical> is where you get your name. But not your given name, your <kanji>family name</kanji>. That's why people have names that mean "in a rice paddy" and "near the ferry crossing." The location of your clan determined your <kanji>surname</kanji>! Hope your ancestors didn't live on "Poo Lake" or something.
meaningInfo: Think about your own surname in your language. Where did it come from? Were you a clan of village dwellers? Maybe you made shoes! You should look it up and find out!
readingMnemonic: Don't worry, I'll tell you where your <kanji>family name</kanji> came from. Your family used to herd <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>). You read that right, your family was of the sheep clan because you took care of sheep all day.
readingInfo: Imagine your ancestors, herding sheep. Thanks to them your name means "sheep people." Thanks, great-great-great-great-great-grandpappy.
userMnemonic: see the C and L for <kan>Clan</kan>, which is what your <kan>surname</kan> refers to
